description: From French prétexte, from Latin praetextum (“an ornament, etc., wrought in front, a pretense”), neuter of praetextus, past participle of praetexere (“to weave before, fringe or border, allege”).

entries.meaning: A false, contrived, or assumed purpose or reason; a pretense.
examples: The reporter called the company on the pretext of trying to resolve a consumer complaint.

verbs.description: pretext (third-person singular simple present pretexts, present participle pretexting, simple past and past participle pretexted)

entries.meaning: To employ a pretext, which involves using a false or contrived purpose for soliciting the gain of something else.
examples: The spy obtained his phone records using possibly-illegal pretexting methods.
